titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Steinbeck Collection, 1902-1979 M0263
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tim Noakes

publicationstmt.publisher: Dept. of Special Collections & University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-09-06T12:13-0700

did.unittitle: John Steinbeck collection

repository.corpname: Dept. of Special Collections & University Archives

did.abstract: The collection is primarily letters and documents written by Steinbeck to family, friends and business associates. Also included are letters written to Steinbeck and letters written about him. Includes manuscripts and typescripts of works by Steinbeck, proofs of books, tearsheets, and photocopies of published works by him. Reviews of Steinbeck's work, articles about him, press coverage of his travels, memorabilia, photographs, and artwork complete the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Data organization: Correspondence, 1928-1972 (boxes 1-8), Literary manuscripts, 1923-1975 (boxes 8-12), Photographs, artwork and ephemera, 1902-1979 (boxes 12-17).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection is primarily letters and documents written by Steinbeck to family, friends and business associates. Also included are letters written to Steinbeck and letters written about him. Includes manuscripts and typescripts of works by Steinbeck, proofs of books, tearsheets, and photocopies of published works by him. Reviews of Steinbeck's work, articles about him, press coverage of his travels, memorabilia, photographs, and artwork complete the collection.

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: John Ernst Steinbeck was born in Salinas, California 27 February 1902. He was the author of short stories and novels, of which some became plays and films. He died in New York City 20 December 1968.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gifts and purchases from various sources.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: John Steinbeck collection, M0263. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: The library does not have full title to the portion of the collection comprising Steinbeck's letters to Elaine Steinbeck (78-011). This material cannot be photocopied without first obtaining permission through Julie Fallowfield at the address below.

Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least 24 hours in advance of intended use.

Typescripts of Minor Pieces: To An Elephant Who Was Sad; untitled piece regarding Robert Capa; The Articles of War; Are We Morally Flabby; Surging Thirties; untitled regarding the history of the migrant people since The Grapes of Wrath; untitled regarding Steinbeck's typing.

Typescripts of Minor Pieces: untitled article regarding Carl Sandburg; Untitled Piece; Atque Vale, Some Random Thoughts on Life Insurance as An Anti-survival Factor in the American Male; list of aphorisms, Egg Heads of the World Arise; Introduction; Circus.
Typescripts of Minor Pieces: Old Cars; River Folk: A Sketch; A Pox on All Your Ages; Manuscript for Holiday Magazine; An Innocent Journey; The Red Pony Suite; El Camion Vacilador.

Typescripts of Minor Pieces: She was a Widgeon of Delight; The Excavations under St. Peter; Monagesque Fallout; The Queen's Birthday; Three Coins Down theDrain; London Interview; Midsummer; Clean out the Icebox; A Desperate Remedy; Gusher, Florentine Fashion; Sholokoff; Explode Sweet Chariot; See Naples and Die; Mare Nostrum; It's a Treat to Beat your Feet; Homesickness.

Ledger: Manuscript fragment, "The God in the Pipes" (1939) [see Working Days]. Includes "Mrs. Van Deventer and Daughter," "The Maltbys," "The Lopez Sisters," "The Deserted Farm," "Miss Morgan," "Raymond Banks," "John Whiteside and His House," "Pat Humbert," "Second Version," fragment about a boy named Mizpah.
